snp1.1:1.1.eng: When anger surges, they drive it out,

snp1.1:1.2.eng: as with medicine a snake’s spreading venom.

snp1.1:1.3.eng: Such a mendicant sheds the near shore and the far,

snp1.1:1.4.eng: as a serpent its old worn-out skin.

snp1.1:2.2.eng: like a lotus plucked flower and stalk.

snp1.1:2.3.eng: Such a mendicant sheds the near shore and the far,
snp1.1:2.3.comm: In SN 35.241, the “near shore” is the six interior senses and the “far shore” is the six exterior senses.

snp1.1:2.4.eng: as a serpent its old worn-out skin.

snp1.1:3.3.eng: Such a mendicant sheds the near shore and the far,

snp1.1:3.4.eng: as a serpent its old worn-out skin.

snp1.1:4.2.eng: as a fragile bridge of reeds by a great flood.

snp1.1:4.3.eng: Such a mendicant sheds the near shore and the far,

snp1.1:4.4.eng: as a serpent its old worn-out skin.

snp1.1:5.1.eng: In future lives they find no worth,

snp1.1:5.2.eng: as an inspector of fig trees finds no flower.

snp1.1:5.3.eng: Such a mendicant sheds the near shore and the far,

snp1.1:5.4.eng: as a serpent its old worn-out skin.

snp1.1:6.2.eng: passed beyond any kind of existence.

snp1.1:6.3.eng: Such a mendicant sheds the near shore and the far,

snp1.1:6.4.eng: as a serpent its old worn-out skin.

snp1.1:7.1.eng: Their mental vibrations are cleared away,
snp1.1:7.1.comm: The commentary interprets vitakka as “wrong thoughts”, but the identical line at Ud 6.7:4.1 clearly refers to jhāna. The commentary also reads vidhūpitā as “burning up”, but vidhūpa refers to clearing the mist, smoke, or incense.

snp1.1:7.3.eng: Such a mendicant sheds the near shore and the far,

snp1.1:7.4.eng: as a serpent its old worn-out skin.

snp1.1:8.1.eng: They have not run too far nor run back,

snp1.1:8.2.eng: but have gone beyond all this proliferation.

snp1.1:8.3.eng: Such a mendicant sheds the near shore and the far,

snp1.1:8.4.eng: as a serpent its old worn-out skin.

snp1.1:9.1.eng: They have not run too far nor run back,

snp1.1:9.2.eng: for they know that nothing in the world <j>is what it seems.
snp1.1:9.2.comm: Bodhi, Norman, and Ṭhānissaro all render vitatha as “unreal”. This seems overly idealistic for early Buddhism, so I take the prefix vi in the sense of “distorts”, “twists”.

snp1.1:9.3.eng: Such a mendicant sheds the near shore and the far,

snp1.1:9.4.eng: as a serpent its old worn-out skin.

snp1.1:10.1.eng: They have not run too far nor run back,

snp1.1:10.2.eng: knowing nothing is what it seems, free of greed.

snp1.1:10.3.eng: Such a mendicant sheds the near shore and the far,

snp1.1:10.4.eng: as a serpent its old worn-out skin.

snp1.1:11.1.eng: They have not run too far nor run back,

snp1.1:11.2.eng: knowing nothing is what it seems, free of lust.

snp1.1:11.3.eng: Such a mendicant sheds the near shore and the far,

snp1.1:11.4.eng: as a serpent its old worn-out skin.

snp1.1:12.1.eng: They have not run too far nor run back,

snp1.1:12.2.eng: knowing nothing is what it seems, free of hate.

snp1.1:12.3.eng: Such a mendicant sheds the near shore and the far,

snp1.1:12.4.eng: as a serpent its old worn-out skin.

snp1.1:13.1.eng: They have not run too far nor run back,

snp1.1:13.2.eng: knowing nothing is what it seems, free of delusion.

snp1.1:13.3.eng: Such a mendicant sheds the near shore and the far,

snp1.1:13.4.eng: as a serpent its old worn-out skin.

snp1.1:14.1.eng: They have no underlying tendencies at all,

snp1.1:14.2.eng: and are rid of unskillful roots,

snp1.1:14.3.eng: Such a mendicant sheds the near shore and the far,

snp1.1:14.4.eng: as a serpent its old worn-out skin.

snp1.1:15.1.eng: They have nothing born of distress at all

snp1.1:15.2.eng: to make them to return to the near shore.

snp1.1:15.3.eng: Such a mendicant sheds the near shore and the far,

snp1.1:15.4.eng: as a serpent its old worn-out skin.

snp1.1:16.1.eng: No snarl grows in them at alll,

snp1.1:16.2.eng: that would shackle them to a new life.

snp1.1:16.3.eng: Such a mendicant sheds the near shore and the far,

snp1.1:16.4.eng: as a serpent its old worn-out skin.

snp1.1:17.1.eng: They’ve given up the five hindrances,

snp1.1:17.2.eng: untroubled, rid of indecision, free of thorns.

snp1.1:17.3.eng: Such a mendicant sheds the near shore and the far,

snp1.1:17.4.eng: as a serpent its old worn-out skin.

snp1.10:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā āḷaviyaṃ viharati āḷavakassa yakkhassa bhavane.
snp1.10:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Āḷavī in the haunt of the native spirit Āḷavaka.

snp1.10:1.3.pli: Atha kho āḷavako yakkho yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
snp1.10:1.3.eng: Then the native spirit Āḷavaka went up to the Buddha, and said to him:

snp1.10:1.5.eng: Saying, “All right, good sir,” the Buddha went out.

snp1.10:1.7.eng: Saying, “All right, good sir,” the Buddha went in.

snp1.10:2.2.pli: tatiyampi kho āḷavako yakkho bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
snp1.10:2.2.eng: And for a third time the native spirit Āḷavaka said to the Buddha,

snp1.10:2.4.eng: Saying, “All right, good sir,” the Buddha went out.

snp1.10:2.6.eng: Saying, “All right, good sir,” the Buddha went in.

snp1.10:3.1.pli: Catutthampi kho āḷavako yakkho bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
snp1.10:3.1.eng: And for a fourth time the native spirit Āḷavaka said to the Buddha,

snp1.10:3.3.eng: “No, good sir, I won’t get out.

snp1.10:4.1.eng: “I will ask you a question, ascetic.

snp1.10:4.2.pli: Sace me na byākarissasi, cittaṃ vā te khipissāmi, hadayaṃ vā te phālessāmi, pādesu vā gahetvā pāragaṅgāya khipissāmī”ti.
snp1.10:4.2.eng: If you don’t answer me, I’ll drive you insane, or explode your heart, or grab you by the feet and throw you to the far shore of the Ganges!”

snp1.10:5.1.pli: “Na khvāhaṃ taṃ, āvuso, passāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya yo me cittaṃ vā khipeyya hadayaṃ vā phāleyya pādesu vā gahetvā pāragaṅgāya khipeyya.
snp1.10:5.1.eng: “I don’t see anyone in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans who could do that to me.

snp1.10:5.2.pli: Api ca tvaṃ, āvuso, puccha yadākaṅkhasī”ti.
snp1.10:5.2.eng: But anyway, ask what you wish.”

snp1.10:5.3.pli: Atha kho āḷavako yakkho bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
snp1.10:5.3.eng: Then the native spirit Āḷavaka addressed the Buddha in verse:

snp1.10:6.2.eng: What brings happiness when practiced well?

snp1.10:6.3.eng: What’s the sweetest taste of all?

snp1.10:6.4.eng: The one they say has the best life: how do they live?”

snp1.10:7.1.eng: “Faith here is a person’s best wealth.

snp1.10:7.2.eng: the teaching brings happiness when practiced well.

snp1.10:7.3.eng: Truth is the sweetest taste of all.

snp1.10:7.4.eng: The one they say has the best life lives by wisdom.”

snp1.10:8.2.eng: How do you cross the deluge?

snp1.10:8.3.eng: How do you get over suffering?

snp1.10:9.3.eng: By energy you get past suffering,

snp1.10:10.3.eng: How do you get a good reputation?

snp1.10:10.4.eng: How do you hold on to friends?

snp1.10:10.5.eng: How do the departed not grieve

snp1.10:10.6.eng: when passing from this world to the next?”

snp1.10:11.2.eng: gains wisdom by wanting to learn,

snp1.10:11.3.eng: having faith in the perfected ones,

snp1.10:11.4.eng: and the teaching for becoming extinguished.

snp1.10:12.2.eng: and working hard you earn wealth.

snp1.10:12.3.eng: Truthfulness wins you a good reputation.

snp1.10:12.4.eng: You hold on to friends by giving.

snp1.10:13.3.eng: does not grieve after passing away:

snp1.10:14.1.eng: Go ahead, ask others as well,

snp1.10:14.2.eng: there are many ascetics and brahmins.

snp1.10:14.3.eng: See whether anything better is found

snp1.10:14.4.eng: than truth, principle, generosity, and patience.”

snp1.10:15.4.eng: what’s good for the next life.

snp1.10:16.1.eng: It was truly for my benefit

snp1.10:16.2.eng: that the Buddha came to stay at Āḷavī.

snp1.10:16.4.eng: where a gift is very fruitful.

snp1.10:17.2.eng: village to village, town to town,

snp1.10:17.4.eng: and the clear rightness of the teaching!”

snp1.11:0.2.eng: Victory Over Desire for the Body

snp1.11:1.4.eng: these are the movements of the body.

snp1.11:2.1.eng: Linked together by bones and sinews,

snp1.11:2.2.eng: plastered over with flesh and hide,

snp1.11:2.4.eng: the body is not seen as it is.

snp1.11:3.1.eng: It’s full of guts and belly,

snp1.11:5.3.eng: There is muck from the eyes,

snp1.11:6.4.eng: And from the body, sweat and waste.

snp1.11:7.1.eng: Then there is the hollow head

snp1.11:9.3.eng: It’s devoured by crows and vultures,

snp1.11:10.4.eng: for they see it as it is.

snp1.11:11.2.eng: as that is, so is this.”

snp1.11:11.3.eng: They’d blanch desire for the body

snp1.11:12.3.eng: has found the peace free of death,

snp1.11:12.4.eng: extinguishment, the state that does not pass.

snp1.11:13.1.eng: This two-legged body is dirty and stinking,

snp1.11:13.3.eng: and oozing all over the place—

snp1.11:14.1.eng: And if, on account of such a body,

snp1.11:14.4.eng: what is that but a failure to see?

snp1.12:2.1.eng: Having cut down what’s grown, <j>they wouldn’t replant,

snp1.12:2.2.eng: nor would they nurture what’s growing.

snp1.12:2.3.eng: That’s who they call a sage wandering alone,

snp1.12:2.4.eng: the great seer has seen the state of peace.

snp1.12:3.1.eng: Having appraised the fields and measured the seeds,
snp1.12:3.1.comm: Taking pamāya as an absolutive of pamiṇāti per Snp 4.12:17.1, against the commentary’s sense of “crushed” (Sanskrit: pramṛṇati).

snp1.12:3.2.eng: they wouldn’t nurture them with moisture.

snp1.12:3.3.eng: Truly that sage who sees the ending of rebirth

snp1.12:3.4.eng: has left speculation behind and is beyond reckoning.
snp1.12:3.4.comm: Compare the stock idiom Saṅkhampi na upeti at eg. SN 20.2:1.7; also Snp 5.7:6.3.

snp1.12:4.1.eng: Understanding all the planes of rebirth,

snp1.12:4.2.eng: not wanting a single one of them,

snp1.12:4.3.eng: Truly that sage freed of greed

snp1.12:4.4.eng: need not swim, <j>for they have reached the far shore.

snp1.12:5.1.eng: The champion, all-knower, so very intelligent,

snp1.12:5.2.eng: unsullied in the midst of all things,

snp1.12:5.3.eng: has given up all, freed in the ending of craving:

snp1.12:5.4.eng: that’s who the attentive know as a sage.

snp1.12:6.1.eng: Strong in wisdom, <j>with precepts and observances intact,

snp1.12:6.4.eng: that’s who the attentive know as a sage.

snp1.12:7.2.eng: is unshaken by blame and praise—

snp1.12:7.3.eng: like a lion not startled by sounds,

snp1.12:7.4.eng: like wind not caught in a net,

snp1.12:7.5.eng: like water not sticking to a lotus.

snp1.12:7.6.eng: Leader of others, not by others led:

snp1.12:7.7.eng: that’s who the attentive know as a sage.

snp1.12:8.1.eng: Steady as a post in a bathing-place

snp1.12:8.2.eng: when others speak endlessly against them,

snp1.12:8.3.eng: freed of greed, with senses stilled:

snp1.12:8.4.eng: that’s who the attentive know as a sage.

snp1.12:9.3.eng: discerning the just and the unjust:

snp1.12:9.4.eng: that’s who the attentive know as a sage.

snp1.12:10.2.eng: young or middle-aged, the sage is self-controlled.

snp1.12:10.3.eng: Irreproachable, he does not insult anyone:

snp1.12:10.4.eng: that’s who the attentive know as a sage.

snp1.12:11.1.eng: When one who lives on charity receives alms,

snp1.12:11.2.eng: from the top, the middle, or the leftovers,

snp1.12:11.3.eng: they think it unworthy to praise or put down:

snp1.12:11.4.eng: that’s who the attentive know as a sage.

snp1.12:12.1.eng: The sage lives refraining from sex,

snp1.12:12.2.eng: even when young is not tied down,

snp1.12:12.3.eng: refraining from indulgence and negligence, freed:

snp1.12:12.4.eng: that’s who the attentive know as a sage.

snp1.12:13.1.eng: Understanding the world, <j>the seer of the ultimate goal,

snp1.12:13.2.eng: the unaffected one, <j>having crossed the flood and the ocean,

snp1.12:13.3.eng: has cut the ties, unattached and undefiled:

snp1.12:13.4.eng: that’s who the attentive know as a sage.

snp1.12:14.1.eng: The two are not the same, <j>far apart in lifestyle and conduct—

snp1.12:14.2.eng: the householder providing for a wife, <j>and the selfless one true to their vows.

snp1.12:14.3.eng: The unrestrained householder kills other creatures,

snp1.12:14.4.eng: while the restrained sage <j>always protects living creatures.

snp1.12:15.1.eng: As the crested blue-necked peacock <j>flying through the sky

snp1.12:15.2.eng: never approaches the speed of the swan,

snp1.12:15.3.eng: so the householder cannot compete <j>with the mendicant,

snp1.12:15.4.eng: the sage meditating secluded in the woods.
